headline: CUSMA-compliant auto parts won't be hit with tariffs | CBC News
context: U.S. Customs and Border Protection guidance released today says automobile parts compliant with the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement on trade will not be hit with U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs.

annotations.reason: This is a credit line and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: CUSMA-compliant auto parts won't be hit with tariffs | Hanomansing Tonight
annotations.reason: This is a program title and does not contribute to the article's core story.

annotations.paragraph: U.S. Customs and Border Protection guidance released on Thursday says automobile parts compliant with the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) on trade will not be hit with U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential information about the exemption of CUSMA-compliant auto parts from tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: It's the latest sign of relief for the deeply integrated North American automobile industry besieged by multiple levels of tariffs.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the impact of tariffs on the North American automobile industry.

annotations.paragraph: Trump slapped a 25 per cent tariff on all vehicle imports to the United States last month, but made a carveout for the American-made parts of cars compliant with the continental trade pact, also called CUSMA.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the tariffs and the exemption for CUSMA-compliant parts.

annotations.paragraph: The White House originally said they were looking to develop a similar scheme for auto part imports compliant with CUSMA before those duties were set to go into place on Saturday.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the initial plans for tariffs and their timing.

annotations.paragraph: Industry and experts said it would be extremely cumbersome and complicated to figure out a way to only tariff non-American components of auto parts. Auto parts can cross the border between Canada and the United States multiple times before a vehicle is finished.
annotations.reason: Explains the complexity of implementing tariffs on non-American components.

annotations.paragraph: "At the end of the day, we have a highly integrated industry," said Huw Williams, the national spokesperson for the Canadian Automobile Dealers Association, when speaking to CBC News Network on Thursday.
annotations.reason: Provides a quote emphasizing the integration of the auto industry.

annotations.paragraph: "What we want to have is one unified auto sector, and the U.S. has been slow to understand how highly integrated it is."
annotations.reason: Offers a perspective on the desired outcome for the auto sector.

annotations.paragraph: U.S. Customs and Border Protection guidance says the exemption does not apply to automobile knock-down kits or parts compilations.
annotations.reason: Clarifies specific exemptions to the tariff rule.

annotations.paragraph: The Big Three — Ford, General Motors and Stellantis — had been lobbying the Trump administration for months, saying the duties would drive up prices and devastate the North American industry. General Motors CEO Mary Barra warned on Thursday that the tariffs could cost the company up to $5 billion.
annotations.reason: Provides context on industry lobbying and potential financial impact of tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Trump gave the auto industry a bit of reprieve on Tuesday saying he just wanted to "help them endure this little transition, short term."
annotations.reason: Offers direct commentary from Trump relevant to the tariff situation.

annotations.paragraph: He signed an executive order so that companies paying the automobile tariffs won't see some other levies — including the 25 per cent duties on steel and aluminum — stacked on top of each other.
annotations.reason: Details an executive order related to tariffs, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Trump also signed an executive order offering automakers that finish their vehicles in the U.S. a rebate on imported auto parts that is equal to 15 per cent of a vehicle's retail price. The rebate would drop to 10 per cent the following year.
annotations.reason: Describes a specific policy action affecting auto tariffs, relevant to the article.

annotations.paragraph: The order wasn't clear about what would happen to CUSMA-compliant parts but a fact sheet from the White House later suggested vehicle components under the trade pact would get some sort of break.
annotations.reason: Directly addresses the main premise about CUSMA-compliant parts and tariffs.
